title: Common Source Bias
shortDescription: A cognitive bias in which people overestimate the connection between events if they come from the same source.
fullDescription:
Common source bias occurs when people begin to perceive a connection between events or facts simply because they come from the same source, even though these events might not actually be related. This bias often manifests in people's tendency to ignore the independence of data and to seek causal relationships where there are none. For example, a person might believe that two pieces of information coming from the same source necessarily confirm each other, even though it may just be a coincidence.

This cognitive bias is especially noticeable when information comes from the same channel, which can create an illusion of interdependence of data. Such thinking leads to false conclusions and can distort the perception of reality, especially in situations that require objective analysis of information.

In the context of information noise and media consumption, common source bias becomes stronger, as people tend to trust familiar or authoritative information sources without verifying the actual correlation of events. To avoid this bias, it's important to separate independent events and analyze data based on its own value rather than relying on a common source.
advices: Separate independent events and evaluate them independently, without relying on a common source.
Analyze information objectively, verifying the accuracy of data from various sources.
Be cautious with information that comes from the same source, even if it appears reliable.
examples: Emma believes that if two news stories come from the same source, they must be related.
John thinks that if two companies have the same owner, their success or failure must be interconnected.
Michael assumes that if two articles refer to the same study, they confirm each other.

questions.text: Michael is sure that two products released by the same company are equally successful. Which cognitive bias does this illustrate?
questions.answerExplanation: Common Source Bias: Michael believes that the two products are linked simply because they come from the same source.

questions.text: Anna thinks that two articles written by the same author must validate each other. Which cognitive bias does this describe?
questions.answerExplanation: Common Source Bias: Anna mistakenly assumes that the articles validate each other because of the shared author.
